questions.text: A patient has presented for a routine eye evaluation. You have checked his visual acuity using Snellen's chart and found it to be 6/6. What is the minimum angle of resolution? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 5 minutes of arc

 

The angle subtended for a patient with 6/6 vision is 5 minutes of arc.

 

Visual acuity is a measure of the spatial resolution of the eye or an estimation of its ability to discriminate between two points.

 

Snellen's chart consists of a series of letters arranged in lines, each diminishing in size. Each whole letter will subtend the angle of 5 minutes at the nodal point of the eye at the given distance.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The minimum angle of resolution for someone with a visual acuity of 6/6 using a Snellen chart is 5 minutes of arc. This indicates the precise and detailed visual capability required to resolve fine details at a standard distance, a fundamental concept in understanding and assessing visual acuity in clinical settings.

questions.text: A patient presents with vision problem in his right eye. On examination IOP of his right eye is 50 mmHg and left eye is 16 mm Hg. Slit lamp examination shows presence of flare cells in anterior chamber and cataractous lens in the right eye. What is the diagnosis of this condition? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phacolytic glaucoma


Phacolytic glaucoma occurs when high intraocular pressure (IOP) is associated with a mature or hypermature cataract. The patient's right eye exhibits high IOP (50 mmHg), flare cells in the anterior chamber, and a cataractous lens, all of which are characteristic signs of phacolytic glaucoma. The leakage of lens material into the anterior chamber induces an inflammatory response, causing the observed clinical signs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malignant glaucoma: This condition typically features a shallow or flat anterior chamber, which contrasts with the described deep anterior chamber. Therefore, it is not consistent with the clinical findings of this patient.

 

Option C. Fuch heterochromic iridocyclitis: This is usually a unilateral condition characterized by chronic inflammation, heterochromia (differences in iris color), and low-grade inflammation. It does not typically present with such high IOP or a cataractous lens as the primary issue.

 

Option D. Phacomorphic glaucoma: This type of glaucoma occurs due to lens-induced angle closure and is associated with a shallow anterior chamber. The patient, however, has a deep anterior chamber, which rules out this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:


Phacolytic glaucoma is characterized by high intraocular pressure, presence of flare cells in the anterior chamber, and a cataractous lens.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented with lagophthalmos, orbicularis oculi palsy, and loss of corneal sensation. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mycobacterium leprae

 

Based on the ocular manifestations of leprosy, Mycobacterium leprae is the most likely causative organism.

 

  • Ocular symptoms include:
    • Lagophthalmos (inability to close the eyelids) due to the involvement of the zygomatic branch of the facial nerve. Other causes of lagophthalmos include extreme proptosis (bulging of the eyes) and symblepharon (adhesion of the eyelids to the eyeball).
    • Corneal anesthesia is due to the involvement of the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve, which innervates the cornea.
    • Corneal ulceration
    • Episcleritis
    • Iris atrophy
  • In addition, patients may present with:
    • Cataract,
    • Glaucoma,
    • Madarosis (loss of eyelashes or eyebrows)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Acanthamoeba castellanii

 

  • Acanthamoeba castellanii can cause acanthamoeba keratitis.
  • Symptoms include pain, lacrimation, photophobia, and foreign body sensation.
  • Results from direct corneal contact with infected material.
  • Contact lens users are at an increased risk.
  • Radial keratoneuritis is pathognomonic.

 

Option C: Onchocerca volvulus

 

  • Onchocerca volvulus causes onchocerciasis, commonly seen in African countries.
  • Symptoms include sclerosing keratitis, uveitis, chorioretinitis, and optic neuritis.
  • Ultimately, it can lead to optic atrophy.

 

Option D: Chlamydia A to C

 

  • Chlamydia trachomatis serovars A, B, Ba, and C are responsible for hyperendemic (blinding) trachoma.
  • The source of infection is infected conjunctival discharge.
  • If there is no secondary bacterial infection, symptoms include lacrimation, scanty mucoid discharge, and foreign body sensation.
  • Conjunctival congestion and follicles, papillary hyperplasia, Herbert follicles (seen in the limbal area), and progressive pannus are the characteristic features.
  • Serovars D to K cause neonatal and adult inclusion conjunctivitis.
  • Neonates present with conjunctival discharge, chemosis, and swollen lids.
  • Adult inclusion conjunctivitis is more commonly seen in sexually active adults and presents with foreign body sensation, mild photophobia, and mucopurulent discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lagophthalmos, orbicularis oculi palsy, and loss of corneal sensation—are indicative of neurogenic involvement, which is characteristic of leprosy, caused by Mycobacterium leprae.

questions.text:
A pregnant woman presented with total ophthalmoplegia, pulsatile proptosis of the right eye, retroorbital pain accompanied with fever and headache. On examination, fundus and BP were normal. Which of the following structures are involved?

 

  1. Abducens nerve
  2. Oculomotor nerve
  3. Internal carotid artery
  4. Cavernous sinus
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

The clinical presentation of pulsatile proptosis, retroorbital pain, fever, and headache in a pregnant woman suggests the involvement of multiple cranial structures, primarily those associated with the cavernous sinus, a critical venous sinus at the base of the brain that acts as a conduit for venous blood drainage from the brain and eye. This constellation of symptoms and signs is indicative of cavernous sinus thrombosis (CST), a severe and potentially life-threatening condition.

 

  • Cavernous sinus thrombosis (CST) is a septic thrombus formed in the cavernous sinus due to the spread of infection from sinuses, teeth, ears, nose, and skin of the face.
  • Symptoms include fever, severe headache, supraorbital pain, seizures, and edema in the mastoid region.
  • Eye signs include proptosis, chemosis, and diplopia due to ophthalmoplegia from the involvement of oculomotor (CN-III), trochlear (CN-IV), and abducens nerve (CN-VI).
  • Absence of corneal sensation due to the involvement of the ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve (CN-V1)
  • Ipsilateral ptosis, dilated pupil, and absence of direct and consensual pupillary right reflex due to oculomotor nerve palsy.
  • Pulsatile proptosis occurs with the involvement of the internal carotid artery.
  • Brain magnetic resonance imaging or magnetic resonance venography should be done urgently for diagnosis.
  • Management of CST includes intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics, analgesics, anti-inflammatory drugs, and anticoagulants.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the most common ocular manifestation of COVID-19?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Follicular conjunctivitis

 

COVID-19 can cause various ocular manifestations, with follicular conjunctivitis being the most common. This is due to the presence of ACE-2 receptors in the cornea and conjunctiva, making them susceptible to SARS-CoV-2 infection.

 

COVID-19:

 

  • Most common ocular symptoms: Dry eye or foreign body sensation, redness, tearing, itching, eye pain, and discharge.
  • Most common ocular manifestation: Mild follicular conjunctivitis, which can appear as the only sign and symptom of COVID-19.
  • Other less frequent ocular complications: Hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, dry eye disease, episcleritis, chemosis, and photophobia.
  • Intraocular complications that may occur: Retinal artery occlusions, hemorrhages, and cotton wool spots caused by complement-mediated thrombotic angiopathy.
  • Patients with conjunctivitis should undergo a nasopharyngeal RT-PCR test for COVID-19 to rule out systemic infection.
  • Physicians and ophthalmologists should exercise caution when examining patients with conjunctivitis and wear eye-protective gear in addition to face masks and other protective devices.

 

FOLLICULAR CONJUNCTIVITIS:

 

 

  • The follicles appear as gray-white, round to oval elevations which measuring between 0.5 to 1.5 mm in diameter
  • Smaller follicles may produce a slightly irregular and velvety appearance
  • Follicles can be seen in the inferior and superior tarsal conjunctiva, and less often, on bulbar or limbal conjunctiva 
    • Acute follicular conjunctivitis is usually associated with viral (epidemic keratoconjunctivitis, Herpes zoster keratoconjunctivitis, infectious mononucleosis, Epstein-Barr virus infection) or chlamydial infections (Inclusion conjunctivitis), while chronic disease may be caused by chronic chlamydial infection (trachoma, lymphogranuloma venereum) or as a toxic or reactive inflammatory response to topical medications and molluscum contagiosum infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uveitis: There are no consistent reports linking uveitis directly as a common manifestation of COVID-19.

 

Option B. Mucormycosis: Although mucormycosis (commonly known as black fungus) has been seen in COVID-19 patients, it is generally associated with severely immunocompromised states and not directly linked as a typical ocular manifestation of COVID-19 itself.

 

Option D. Papillary Conjunctivitis: This type of conjunctivitis, characterized by cobblestone-like nodules, is more commonly associated with allergic reactions or chronic irritation from contact lenses rather than infectious etiologies like COVID-19.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 80 year old male presented with diminution of vision since 2 years. The right eye was red and painful. On examination, the IOP was 50 mmHg in right eye and 16 mmHg in left eye. The right eye had deep anterior chamber with some cells and flare. What could be the possibility? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phacolytic glaucoma

 

Phacolytic glaucoma is characterized by the leakage of lens proteins through an intact lens capsule, which causes an inflammatory response in the eye. This condition often occurs in elderly patients with hypermature cataracts. The leakage of proteins results in cells and flare in the anterior chamber, as well as a deep anterior chamber. The clinical presentation described in the question, including the deep anterior chamber with cells and flare and the patient's age, aligns with the characteristics of phacolytic glaucoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malignant glaucoma: Malignant glaucoma, also known as aqueous misdirection syndrome, is characterized by a shallow anterior chamber and elevated intraocular pressure (IOP). This condition typically does not present with cells and flare in the anterior chamber, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this case.

 

Option C. Fuch heterochromic iridocyclitis: Fuch heterochromic iridocyclitis usually presents in younger patients, and it is less likely to occur in an 80-year-old individual. This condition is characterized by heterochromia (difference in eye color) and mild anterior uveitis, but it does not typically present with the deep anterior chamber and the level of inflammation described in the question.

 

Option D. Phacomorphic glaucoma: Phacomorphic glaucoma occurs due to the swelling of a mature cataract, which leads to a shallow anterior chamber and increased IOP. The question describes a deep anterior chamber, which is not consistent with phacomorphic glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phacolytic glaucoma presents with a deep anterior chamber, cells and flare due to leakage of lens proteins, and typically occurs in elderly patients with hypermature cataracts.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of keratoconus? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Haab's striae  

 

Haab’s striae are not a feature of Keratoconus. Haab's striae are seen in buphthalmos where the intraocular pressure is raised and the eyeball is enlarged as a whole. The enlarged cornea is associated with tears in Descemet's membrane called Haab's striae.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Munson's sign: Directly associated with keratoconus. It is observed when the patient looks down, causing the lower eyelid to bulge out due to the cone-shaped cornea.

 

Option C. Irregular Astigmatism: A hallmark of keratoconus, resulting from the irregular thinning and bulging of the cornea.

 

Option D. Scissoring Reflex: This is a characteristic finding in keratoconus observed during retinoscopy due to the irregular shape of the cornea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Following signs may be elicited in keratoconus –

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of the optic disc in glaucoma? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Roenne's nasal step

 

  • Roenne's nasal step is not a feature of the optic disc in glaucoma.
  • Roenne's nasal step is a visual field defect. It is the result of two arcuate scotomas running in different arcs and meeting at the horizontal meridian. This forms a right-angled defect in the nasal side of the visual field.

 

Roenne’s nasal step

 

 

  • Early glaucomatous changes:
    • Increase in cup-disc ratio (C/D ratio) to >0.4
    • Splinter hemorrhages near the optic disc margin
    • Atrophy of the retinal nerve fiber layer
  • Advanced glaucomatous changes:
    • Marked increase in C/D ratio (0.7 or more)
    • Thinning of the neuroretinal rim
    • Nasal shifting of the retinal vessels or bayonetting
    • Pulsations of retinal arterioles at the disc margin.
    • If the damage progresses, all neural tissue is destroyed and the optic nerve appears white and deeply excavated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bayonetting: This refers to the appearance of blood vessels on the optic disc where the vessels appear to sharply bend or 'bayonet' due to the structural changes in the optic disc from glaucomatous damage, particularly as the neuroretinal rim thins and the cup enlarges.

 

Option C. Increased cup-disc ratio: A hallmark of glaucomatous damage to the optic nerve, where the optic cup enlarges relative to the overall disc, often exceeding a ratio of 0.5, which is considered abnormal and suggestive of glaucoma.

 

Option D. Baring of nasal arteries: This describes the exposure or baring of the nasal retinal arteries as a result of thinning of the nerve fiber layer in glaucoma. It is a less commonly described feature compared to others but can occur as part of the broader pattern of optic nerve head changes in glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Roenne's nasal step, while indicative of the functional impact of glaucoma, does not represent a direct observation of the optic disc but is rather a manifestation of the disease's effect on the visual field.

questions.text: SAFE strategy for trachoma includes all except? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Evaluation of control program

 

In the SAFE strategy, ‘E’ stands for Environmental improvement with better hygiene and sanitation.

 

Effective interventions for trachoma blindness have been demonstrated in developing nations using the SAFE strategy –

 

  • Surgery (S): Performed to correct trichiasis, which is the inward turning of the eyelashes that can lead to corneal damage and blindness. This intervention helps prevent further damage to the cornea.
  • Antibiotics (A): Used to treat the infection caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis. Mass drug administration is typically used in endemic areas to reduce the prevalence of the infection.
  • Facial cleanliness (F): Encouraged to reduce transmission of the bacterium among community members, especially children who are more susceptible to infection.
  • Environmental improvement (E): Focuses on improving living conditions, such as increasing access to clean water and better sanitation facilities, to reduce the spread of the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient presents with bilateral sudden onset painless vision loss. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diabetic retinopathy

 

Explanation:

 

Bilateral sudden onset painless vision loss is most commonly associated with diabetic retinopathy, particularly in cases of proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) leading to vitreous hemorrhage.

 

  • Diabetic retinopathy can cause vitreous hemorrhage, which results in sudden, painless vision loss.
  • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) is characterized by neovascularization, which can rupture and cause bilateral involvement due to systemic nature of diabetes.
  • Unlike other causes of vision loss, diabetic retinopathy progresses asymptomatically until a significant event like hemorrhage or tractional retinal detachment occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Iridocyclitis: Incorrect. Iridocyclitis (anterior uveitis) causes painful vision loss with redness, photophobia, and keratic precipitates, which are absent in this case.

 

Option C. Acute Congestive Glaucoma: Incorrect. This condition presents with sudden onset painful vision loss, red eye, halos around lights, and raised intraocular pressure. The presence of pain distinguishes it from diabetic retinopathy.

 

Option D. Keratoconus: Incorrect. Keratoconus leads to progressive rather than sudden vision loss and is not typically bilateral at onset. It causes irregular astigmatism but does not cause complete vision loss suddenly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bilateral sudden painless vision loss is most commonly due to diabetic retinopathy, particularly proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) with vitreous hemorrhage.



Diminished Vision Classification

questions.text: In fluorescein angiography, how do microaneurysms typically appear? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperfluorescent dots

 

Explanation: 


In fluorescein angiography (FFA), microaneurysms appear as hyperfluorescent dots. Microaneurysms are focal saccular dilatations of capillary walls where pericytes are absent, typically located in the outer plexiform layer and inner nuclear layer. When fluorescein dye is injected, these microaneurysms fill with the dye and appear as bright, well-defined hyperfluorescent dots, particularly visible at the edge of areas of capillary non-perfusion.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Hypofluorescent spots: This is incorrect. Hypofluorescent spots are typically seen in areas of blockage (like hemorrhages) or capillary dropout, not microaneurysms.

 

Option C. Fluorescent leakage: This is incorrect. While microaneurysms may eventually leak, their characteristic initial appearance is as discrete hyperfluorescent dots, not diffuse leakage.

 

Option D. Dark shadows: This is incorrect. Dark shadows or blocking defects are typically seen with hemorrhages or pigmented lesions, not microaneurysms.

 

Educational Objective: 


Microaneurysms appear as hyperfluorescent dots on fluorescein angiography, serving as an important diagnostic feature in conditions like diabetic retinopathy.

questions.text:
Which of the following organisms are associated with acute haemorrhagic conjunctivitis? (INICET MAY 2025)

 

I. Coxsackie B
II. Coxsackie A
III. Enterovirus 70
IV. Polio virus
questions.solution:
Ans. D) I, II and III

 

  • Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis is characterized by sudden onset of multiple subconjunctival hemorrhages along with typical features of viral conjunctivitis. The mnemonic "PACE" helps remember the causative organisms: Picornavirus, Adenovirus, Coxsackievirus, and Enterovirus. Among the options given, Coxsackievirus A (particularly A24 variant), Coxsackievirus B, and Enterovirus 70 are all established causes of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis. 
  • These are all members of the Picornavirus family. The condition presents with dramatic subconjunctival hemorrhages, redness, excessive tearing, and foreign body sensation. It's typically self-limiting and requires only supportive care, though strict hygiene measures are essential to prevent transmission within households and communities.

 

 

Incorrect Option:

 

Polio virus (Statement IV): Although polio virus belongs to the enterovirus genus of picornaviruses, it is not known to cause hemorrhagic conjunctivitis. Polio virus primarily affects the nervous system, causing poliomyelitis, and does not have tropism for conjunctival tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis is caused by Coxsackievirus A24, Coxsackievirus B, Enterovirus 70, and Adenovirus, but not by Polio virus.

 

Note - HAEMORRHAGIC CONJUNCTIVITIS

 

Self-Limiting

 

Symptoms:

 

  • Redness and swelling of the eyelids and conjunctiva.
  • Excessive tearing (epiphora).
  • Foreign body sensation in the eye.
  • Pain or irritation.
  • Photophobia
  • Subconjunctival hemorrhage

 

Management:

 

Supportive Care: Treatment focuses on relieving symptoms like pain and irritation.

 

No Specific Antiviral Treatment: There is no specific antiviral medication, and antibiotics are not effective against viral infections.

questions.text:
Which of the following has familial inheritance? (INICET May 2022)

 

  1. Retinoblastoma
  2. Retinitis pigmentosa
  3. Муоріа
  4. Primary open angle glaucoma
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

All the above conditions (1, 2, 3, 4) have a familial inheritance.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retinoblastoma, Retinitis pigmentosa, Myopia, and Primary open-angle glaucoma — exhibit familial inheritance patterns, meaning they can be passed down through families, indicating genetic influences.

questions.text: 22-year-old patient with high myopia and thick glasses presents with floaters in his eyes. What is the cause of this condition? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Retinal detachment

 

Retinal detachment occurs when the sensory retina separates from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium. This separation can be due to a retinal break, known as rhegmatogenous retinal detachment, which is the most common type. In patients with high myopia, there is an increased risk of peripheral retinal degeneration, leading to retinal holes that can progress to retinal detachment. The presence of floaters and flashes is a key symptom indicating retinal detachment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subarachnoid hemorrhage: This condition typically presents with sudden severe headache and neurological symptoms rather than visual symptoms like floaters.

 

Option C. Vitreous hemorrhage: While this can cause floaters, it is more commonly associated with trauma, diabetic retinopathy, or vascular abnormalities rather than high myopia.

 

Option D. Branched retinal artery occlusion: This condition usually presents with sudden, painless loss of vision in part of the visual field rather than floaters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with high myopia are at increased risk for peripheral retinal degeneration and subsequent retinal detachment, presenting with symptoms like floaters and flashes.

questions.text: Following instrument is used to measure: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Proptosis

 

The image shows a Hertel exophthalmometer, which is specifically designed to measure proptosis—the forward displacement of the eye. 

 

This instrument directly measures how much the eyeball protrudes forward from the eye socket. It is essential in diagnosing conditions like thyroid eye disease where proptosis is a common feature.

 

  • Design and Use: It consists of a ruler and two lateral mirrors or prisms that align with the lateral orbital rim, allowing for accurate measurement of the anterior position of the cornea relative to the lateral orbital wall.
    1. Bilateral Assessment: The Hertel exophthalmometer can measure the protrusion of both eyes simultaneously, allowing for comparison between the two. This is vital for identifying asymmetrical proptosis, which can be an indicator of more serious unilateral orbital disease.
    2. Quantitative Data: It provides quantitative data that can help in monitoring the progression or resolution of orbital diseases over time. This is particularly useful in tracking the effectiveness of treatment for conditions that cause proptosis.
    3. Simple and Non-invasive: The device is straightforward to use and non-invasive, making it a patient-friendly tool for regular follow-up assessments in clinical settings.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Hertel exophthalmometer is a specialized tool for assessing the extent of proptosis in conditions affecting the orbit and surrounding tissues, helping guide further diagnostic and therapeutic steps for conditions like thyroid eye disease.

choices.text: Vision less than 6/60 in better eye after best possible correction
Presenting vision less than 3/60 in better eye
Best corrected vision less than 3/60 in better eye
Vision less than 6/60 in better eye after correction

questions.text: What is the definition of blindness as per NPCB, India? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Presenting vision less than 3/60 in better eye

 

  • The National Programme for Control of Blindness (NPCB) in India has recently modified its definition of blindness to better understand the burden of disease. The current definition uses presenting vision less than 3/60 in the better eye. This change from "best corrected visual acuity" to "presenting vision" was made to more accurately assess the true burden of blindness in the population. 
  • Using presenting vision captures patients who are functionally blind due to uncorrected refractive errors or untreated cataracts, even though they could potentially see better with appropriate intervention. This helps identify cataract and refractive errors as major causes of blindness, as many patients present with vision less than 3/60 that could be improved with surgery or glasses. This definition better reflects the real-world visual status of the population and helps in planning public health interventions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vision less than 6/60 in better eye after best possible correction: This is incorrect on two counts. First, the cutoff for blindness is 3/60, not 6/60 (6/60 is the cutoff for visual impairment, not blindness). Second, current NPCB guidelines use presenting vision, not best corrected vision.

 

Option C. Best corrected vision less than 3/60 in better eye: While this was the conventional definition earlier used by NPCB, it has been modified. Using best corrected visual acuity would underestimate the burden of blindness because it would exclude patients who are blind due to treatable conditions like cataracts or uncorrected refractive errors. After correction, these patients might achieve better vision than 3/60, thus not counting as blind despite being functionally blind in their daily lives.

 

Option D. Vision less than 6/60 in better eye after correction: This is incorrect because the threshold for blindness is 3/60, not 6/60. Vision less than 6/60 but better than or equal to 3/60 is classified as severe visual impairment, not blindness. Additionally, the current definition uses presenting vision, not corrected vision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NPCB currently defines blindness as presenting vision less than 3/60 in the better eye to accurately assess the burden of preventable blindness in India.

questions.text: A 50-year-old emmetropic man is no longer able to read with the presbyopic glasses he had made 5 years ago. The power of his new prescription glasses should be:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. +2D

 

Since, the question asks for the new prescription, the answer should be +2.00D.

 

Had the question asked us to estimate the power of his old glasses, it would have been +1.5 DS.

 

The power of the prescription glasses for a 50-year-old man should be +2D.

 

This condition of falling near vision due to age-related decrease in the amplitude of accommodation or increase in punctum proximum is called presbyopia.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Emmetropic Man: The patient has no refractive error for distance vision but is experiencing difficulty with near vision due to presbyopia.
  • Current Glasses: If the patient had glasses made 5 years ago (when he was around 45), those glasses were likely around +1.5 D.
  • New Prescription: As presbyopia progresses, the strength of the glasses needs to be increased to +2.0 D to accommodate the further decline in near vision.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Roughly, the power of prescription glasses age-wise is as follows:

questions.text: Which type of complication is most commonly associated with advanced diabetic retinopathy? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tractional retinal detachment

 

  • Advanced diabetic retinopathy, particularly proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR), leads to tractional retinal detachment as its characteristic complication. In proliferative diabetic retinopathy, retinal ischemia triggers the release of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), leading to neovascularization at the disc (NVD) and elsewhere (NVE). These new vessels are fragile and leaky, causing vitreous hemorrhage. 
  • When the hemorrhage and fibrovascular proliferation resolve, they form contractile fibrous tissue and tractional bands within the vitreous cavity. These bands exert mechanical traction on the retina, pulling it away from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium, resulting in tractional retinal detachment. This creates characteristic fixed folds and a concave configuration of the detached retina. If the condition progresses further, the continuous traction can create retinal holes, leading to a combined tractional-rhegmatogenous detachment.

 

 

 

Tractional Retinal Detachment

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment: This type of detachment is caused by a break or hole (rhegma) in the retina, allowing fluid from the vitreous cavity to seep underneath and separate the neurosensory retina from the RPE. While advanced diabetic retinopathy can eventually lead to holes due to severe traction (resulting in combined detachment), the primary mechanism in diabetic retinopathy is tractional, not rhegmatogenous. Rhegmatogenous detachment is more commonly associated with high myopia, lattice degeneration, and trauma.

 

Option B. Exudative retinal detachment: This occurs when fluid accumulates beneath the retina without any retinal break or traction. It's caused by conditions that lead to fluid leakage from vessels beneath the retina, such as choroidal neoplasms (melanoma), inflammatory diseases, malignant hypertension, or wet age-related macular degeneration with subretinal neovascular membranes. Diabetic retinopathy does not cause exudative detachment as its primary mechanism involves neovascularization and subsequent fibrosis, not subretinal fluid accumulation.

 

Option D. No retinal detachment: This is incorrect because advanced diabetic retinopathy, particularly proliferative diabetic retinopathy, is well-established to cause retinal detachment. The proliferative changes including neovascularization, vitreous hemorrhage, and subsequent fibrosis are major risk factors for developing tractional retinal detachment, making this one of the most serious sight-threatening complications of advanced diabetic eye disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tractional retinal detachment is the characteristic complication of advanced proliferative diabetic retinopathy, caused by contractile fibrovascular proliferation following neovascularization and vitreous hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with a history of recurrent sinusitis presents with decreased vision, eye protrusion, and fever. A computed tomography (CT) scan was done. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Orbital cellulitis with sinusitis

 

Involves the contents of the orbit including fat and muscle, often secondary to sinus infections, particularly the ethmoid sinus.

 

Symptoms include painful eye movements, protrusion of the eyeball (proptosis), decreased vision, and fever.

 

This condition can be sight-threatening and requires urgent treatment.

 

  • For the 35-year-old male patient with a history of recurrent sinusitis presenting with decreased vision, eye protrusion, and fever, the diagnosis of Orbital cellulitis with sinusitis is most consistent with the symptoms and the findings on the computed tomography (CT) scan. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Preseptal Cellulitis with Sinusitis: Involves the eyelid and skin anterior to the orbital septum, typically without eye protrusion or vision changes.Fever and eyelid swelling are common, but the involvement of the eye as described suggests a deeper infection.

 

Option C. Subperiosteal Abscess: This is an accumulation of pus between the orbit and the periosteum of the orbital bones, typically a complication of orbital cellulitis. It may lead to eye protrusion and restricted eye movements, but it's typically identified on imaging as a distinct abscess rather than generalized infection signs.

 

Option D. Cellulitis: A broad term that can refer to any soft tissue infection but without specifying involvement of the orbital area in relation to the sinuses would be less specific compared to orbital cellulitis with sinusitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orbital cellulitis with sinusitis is a serious condition that requires immediate medical attention to prevent complications such as vision loss, intracranial spread of infection, and other severe outcomes.

choices.text: Irrigation of eye with normal saline

questions.text: A patient presents with a foreign body (chuna) in his eyes and complains of irritability and lacrimation. What is the first step of management in this patient? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Irrigation of eye with normal saline

 

 

 

The initial management for any chemical injury to the eye, including chuna (lime) exposure, is immediate and copious irrigation with normal saline. This step is crucial to wash out the chemical substance from the eye to minimize further damage. Immediate irrigation helps dilute and remove the chemical agent, reducing the risk of severe injury to the ocular tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antibiotics drops in eye: Antibiotic drops are important to prevent infection after the initial management, but they are not the first step. Irrigation must be done first to remove the chemical irritant.

 

Option B. Temporary tarsorrhaphy: Temporary tarsorrhaphy involves partially sewing the eyelids together to protect the eye, but this is not appropriate in the acute phase of a chemical injury. The eye needs to remain open to allow thorough irrigation and drainage of the chemical substance.

 

Option D. Complete Scraping: Complete scraping is a procedure to remove foreign particles embedded in the eye. While this might be necessary if there are chunks of chuna embedded in the conjunctiva, it is not the first step. The initial priority is to irrigate the eye to remove as much of the chemical as possible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first step in the management of chemical injuries to the eye is immediate and copious irrigation with normal saline to wash out the chemical substance

choices.text: 1 – Retinal Pigment Epithelium, 2 – Outer Nuclear Layer, 3 – Inner Plexiform Layer, 4 – Ganglion Cell Layer
1 – Outer Nuclear Layer, 2 – Retinal Pigment Epithelium, 3 – Ganglion Cell Layer, 4 – Inner Plexiform Layer
1 – Ganglion Cell Layer, 2 – Inner Plexiform Layer, 3 – Retinal Pigment Epithelium, 4 – Outer Nuclear Layer
1 – Retinal Pigment Epithelium, 2 – Inner Plexiform Layer, 3 – Outer Nuclear Layer, 4 – Ganglion Cell Layer

questions.text: Arrange the following layers of the retina in the correct order from the outermost to the innermost layer. (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 – Retinal Pigment Epithelium, 2 – Outer Nuclear Layer, 3 – Inner Plexiform Layer, 4 – Ganglion Cell Layer

 

Explanation:


The correct sequence of retinal layers from outermost to innermost is RPE, outer nuclear layer, inner plexiform layer, and ganglion cell layer. The RPE is the outermost layer of the retina, followed by the outer nuclear layer which contains photoreceptor cell bodies. The inner plexiform layer contains synapses between bipolar, amacrine, and ganglion cells, while the ganglion cell layer, containing ganglion cell bodies, is closest to the vitreous.

 

Educational Objective: 


Anatomical sequence of retinal layers from outermost to innermost: 

 

Retinal Pigment Epithelium → Outer Nuclear Layer → Inner Plexiform Layer → Ganglion Cell Layer.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of moderate-severe visual impairment according to the National Blindness and Visual Impairment Survey 2015-19?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Untreated cataract

 

The National Blindness and Visual Impairment Survey conducted from 2015 to 2019 revealed that untreated cataract is the leading cause of moderate-severe visual impairment (MSVI). MSVI is characterized by a presenting visual acuity of <6/18 to 3/60 in the better eye despite available correction. Visual impairment and blindness are frequently observed in individuals who are 50 years old and above.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Refractive errors are the leading cause of MSVI in patients aged 49 years and below.

 

Options C and Option D: Glaucoma and diabetic retinopathy account for a very low number of visual impairment cases in patients aged 50 years and above.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The prevalence of untreated cataracts as a leading cause of moderate-severe visual impairment emphasizes the need for effective public health strategies focusing on eye health screenings and accessible cataract surgery to reduce the burden of preventable blindness and visual impairment.

questions.text: What is the most common tumor of the lacrimal gland? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pleomorphic adenoma

 

Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the lacrimal gland. This tumor is composed of a mix of ductal and myoepithelial cells, often presenting as a painless, progressive, firm mass typically located in the superolateral aspect of the orbit.

 

Details about Pleomorphic Adenoma:

 

  • Benign Nature: Despite its benign nature, pleomorphic adenoma can cause displacement of the eye and may alter vision due to its size and location.
  • Potential for Malignant Transformation: While it is primarily benign, there is a risk for malignant transformation into a carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma if not adequately treated or if left untreated for a long duration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenoid cystic carcinoma: Although this is the most common malignant tumor of the lacrimal gland, it is not as frequently occurring as pleomorphic adenoma. Adenoid cystic carcinoma is known for its aggressive nature and poorer prognosis.

 

Option B. Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma: This type of tumor can involve the lacrimal gland but is generally less common than pleomorphic adenoma.

 

Option D. Mucoepidermoid carcinoma: This is another type of malignant tumor that can occur in the lacrimal gland, but it is also less common than pleomorphic adenoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the lacrimal gland while adenoid cystic carcinoma is the most common malignant tumour of the lacrimal gland. Overall, benign tumours are more common, thus pleomorphic adenoma is the most common lacrimal gland tumour.

questions.text: Which is the investigation of choice for Best disease? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Electrooculogram (EOG)

 

Explanation: 


Electrooculogram (EOG) is the investigation of choice for Best disease. EOG is the only condition where best disease has significant diagnostic value, and Best disease is the only condition where EOG is of primary diagnostic significance. In Best disease, the Arden ratio (peak to trough ratio) in EOG is abnormal (<1.5) while ERG remains normal in early stages. EOG measures the standing potential between the front and back of the eye and is particularly sensitive to RPE function, which is primarily affected in Best disease.

 

Other Options: 


Option B. Electroretinogram (ERG):This is incorrect because ERG is typically normal in Best disease, especially in early stages. ERG measures the electrical response of the retina to light stimulation and primarily tests photoreceptor function.

 

Option C. Multifocal electro retinogram: This is incorrect because mfERG, while useful for evaluating macular function, is not the primary diagnostic test for Best disease. It provides topographic measurement of retinal electrophysiological activity in the central retina.

 

Option D. Visual Evoked potential: This is incorrect because VEP tests the integrity of the entire visual pathway from retina to occipital cortex and is not specific for Best disease. It records the electrical activity in the visual cortex in response to visual stimuli.

 

Educational Objective: 


Electrooculogram (EOG) is the investigation of choice for Best disease, with an abnormal Arden ratio (<1.5) being diagnostic while ERG remains normal in early stages.

questions.text: Which cranial nerve provides sensory innervation to the orbit? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trigeminal nerve

 

  • The sensory innervation of the orbit is provided by the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V), specifically through its ophthalmic and maxillary divisions. The ophthalmic division (V1) provides sensory innervation to the upper eyelid, upper orbital area, forehead, and nasal region, while the maxillary division (V2) supplies the lower eyelid and cheek area. 
  • The trigeminal nerve carries general somatic sensory fibers that provide touch, pain, and temperature sensation to the orbital structures. This includes the skin around the orbit, the conjunctiva, and the extraocular muscles. The trigeminal nerve has three main divisions: ophthalmic (V1), maxillary (V2), and mandibular (V3), with V1 and V2 being the primary contributors to orbital sensation.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vagus nerve: The vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) is primarily responsible for parasympathetic innervation to thoracic and abdominal viscera, as well as some motor functions in the larynx and pharynx. It does not provide sensory innervation to the orbit or any facial structures.

 

Option C. Occulomotor nerve: The oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III) is primarily a motor nerve that innervates four of the six extraocular muscles (superior rectus, inferior rectus, medial rectus, and inferior oblique), the levator palpebrae superioris muscle, and provides parasympathetic fibers to the sphincter pupillae and ciliary muscle. It does not carry sensory fibers for the orbit.

 

Option D. Facial nerve: The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) primarily provides motor innervation to the muscles of facial expression, including the orbicularis oculi muscle around the eye. While it does carry some sensory fibers (for taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and sensation from the external auditory canal), it does not provide the main sensory innervation to the orbital region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The trigeminal nerve, through its ophthalmic (V1) and maxillary (V2) divisions, provides the primary sensory innervation to the orbital region and surrounding structures.

choices.text: Kinetic perimetry is used in quantification and tracking of visual changes in established glaucoma
In Static perimetry, stimulus intensity is held constant and moved centrally with detection
Visual field defect to be classified as glaucoma, it should have the corresponding optic nerve head abnormalities
Early signs include generalised constriction of isopters and barring of blind spot

questions.text: Which of these statements is true regarding perimetry? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Early signs include generalised constriction of isopters and barring of blind spot


Initial indications of glaucoma in perimetry involve a widespread narrowing of isopters and the appearance of a blockage within the blind spot.

 

Perimetry is a diagnostic test used to assess a person's visual field.

 

Static Perimetry: Traditional method involving fixed stimulus points presented on a static grid. Goldmann perimetry and Humphrey Visual Field Analyzer are common devices for static perimetry.

 

Kinetic Perimetry: Moving stimuli are used to determine the boundaries of the visual field. Useful for mapping the extent of peripheral vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Kinetic perimetry involves moving a stimulus across the visual field to map the boundaries of each isopter. It is not specifically used for quantification and tracking of visual changes in established glaucoma; static perimetry is more commonly used for this purpose

 

Option B: In static perimetry, various light spots of different intensities are presented in different locations but do not move across the visual field. The statement in B inaccurately describes kinetic perimetry

 

Option C: While optic nerve head abnormalities are a critical diagnostic feature of glaucoma, visual field defects can exist without clear corresponding optic nerve changes, especially in early or mild cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perimetry is vital for early detection and monitoring of glaucoma. Generalized constriction of isopters and enlargement of the blind spot are key early signs that can indicate the presence of this eye condition.

questions.text: A 14-day-old neonate brought to the outpatient department is found to have bilateral conjunctivitis. Chest X-ray done showed lung infiltrates. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for the infection? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chlamydia trachomatis

 

  • Chlamydia trachomatis is the likely cause of the infection in neonatal conjunctivitis.
  • The infection usually appears 1 week after birth and is transmitted from the mother's cervix or urethra during delivery.
  • Symptoms include edematous conjunctiva, watery discharge that later becomes purulent or bloody.
  • Diagnosis involves taking samples from both the conjunctiva and oropharynx and examining them for intracellular inclusion bodies.
  • Treatment involves administering erythromycin ethylsuccinate 50 mg/kg daily in four divided doses before feeds for 2-3 weeks.
  • If left untreated, associated systemic diseases such as chlamydial otitis and pneumonia may develop later.
  • Both parents must receive appropriate treatment for genital infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemophilus influenzae: This bacterium can cause conjunctivitis but is less likely to present with systemic involvement like pneumonia in the context of neonatal infection.

 

Option C. Streptococcus: While capable of causing neonatal infections, Streptococcus species are more commonly associated with other forms of neonatal morbidity such as sepsis or meningitis, rather than conjunctivitis with pneumonia.

 

Option D. Mycoplasma: It is known to cause respiratory infections in older children and adults but is an uncommon cause of neonatal conjunctivitis or pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neonatal conjunctivitis typically presents during the first month of life and the age of the neonate is an important clue to the infection's etiology.

questions.text: A farmer presents with pain and discharge in his left eye. He says that he sustained an injury caused by a leaf a few days back. What is the finding seen in the image? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypopyon  

 

The finding seen in the image is hypopyon.

 

  • Hypopyon is an accumulation of inflammatory cells in the anterior chamber of the eye, typically seen in the lower part of the chamber as a whitish exudate.
  • In fungal corneal ulcers, the hypopyon may not be sterile as the fungus can penetrate into the anterior chamber without causing a perforation.
  • Hypopyon associated with anterior uveitis is immobile because of the high fibrin content in the exudate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Hyphema is a hemorrhage in the anterior chamber. It commonly occurs after a blunt ocular injury. The bleeding is from the iris root or ciliary body face. The blood settles inferiorly forming a fluid level.

 

 

Option B: Aqueous flare refers to the haziness of the normally clear fluid in the anterior chamber. It reflects the presence of protein due to the breakdown of the blood-aqueous barrier. The presence of flare indicates active inflammation.

 

Option C: Arlt line is the scarring on the conjunctiva in the area of sulcus subtarsalis. It can be a single line, irregularly shaped, or star-shaped. Common causes are trachoma, healed traumatic wounds, or surgical scars.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypopyon is points to severe intraocular inflammation needing prompt treatment to preserve eye function and prevent potential complications. The presence of hypopyon after an injury with organic material highly suggests a fungal etiology, requiring specific antifungal treatment alongside broad-spectrum antibacterial coverage.

questions.text: Pterygium can lead to which of the following? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Astigmatism

 

Explanation: 


Pterygium can lead to astigmatism because the fibrous growth on the cornea tends to flatten the cornea in the horizontal meridian. This creates an irregular corneal surface, specifically causing with-the-rule astigmatism. The pterygium grows along the horizontal axis, making it flatter, which results in the vertical axis becoming comparatively steeper, leading to astigmatism. This condition may cause visual disturbance, especially if it grows across the pupil.

 

Other Options: 


Option B. Eye Pain: This is incorrect. Pterygium is typically painless. Patients may experience foreign body sensation, but actual pain is not a characteristic feature.

 

Option C. Macular edema: This is incorrect. Pterygium is a surface growth that affects the anterior segment of the eye and does not cause macular edema, which is a condition affecting the posterior segment.

 

Option D. Purulent Discharge: This is incorrect. Pterygium is a non-inflammatory condition and does not cause purulent discharge. While there might be mild irritation and tearing, purulent discharge is not associated with pterygium.

 

Educational Objective:


Pterygium can cause with-the-rule astigmatism by flattening the cornea in the horizontal meridian.

questions.text: A patient is prescribed a corrective lens with the following prescription: -1D spherical, -2D cylinder at 180 degrees. What type of refractive error is being corrected? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) With the rule astigmatism

 

  • In the context of refractive errors corrected by lenses, here's an explanation of each type of astigmatism as mentioned:

 

In this condition, the eye's steepest curve is oriented vertically (up and down). This is the most common type of astigmatism. The -2D cylindrical correction at 180 degrees indicates that the correction is applied horizontally, which compensates for the steeper vertical curvature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Against the Rule Astigmatism: Here, the steepest curvature is horizontal (side to side). Corrective lenses for this type would have cylindrical axes oriented vertically (usually at 90 degrees).

 

Option C. Simple Astigmatism: This occurs when one principal meridian is emmetropic (normal), meaning no refractive error, while the other has myopia (short-sightedness) or hyperopia (long-sightedness). There is only one refractive error to correct.

 

Option D. Mixed Astigmatism: This type features one meridian with myopia and the perpendicular meridian with hyperopia. Essentially, one axis is near sighted, and the other is farsighted, requiring complex lens corrections to address both issues simultaneously.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

When prescribed corrective lenses for astigmatism, understanding the orientation and type of astigmatism (with the rule, against the rule, simple, or mixed) is crucial for ensuring the correct lens type and orientation is used, thus maximizing visual clarity and health.

choices.text: Relative afferent pupillary defect is seen.
There is no pain on ocular movement.
Multiple myeloma is a common cause.
Oral corticosteroids are the mainstay of treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about optic neuritis?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Relative afferent pupillary defect is seen.

 

In optic neuritis, a characteristic sign is the presence of a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) or Marcus Gunn pupil. This can be elicited by performing a swinging flashlight test, where a flashlight is moved between the normal and affected eye while observing the pupil response. Normally, both pupils remain constricted when light is shone on them. However, in the presence of RAPD, the pupil in the affected eye will dilate instead of constrict when the light is moved from the normal eye to the affected eye. This paradoxical response of the pupil to light is known as Marcus Gunn pupil, and is an important diagnostic finding in optic neuritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. There is no pain on ocular movement:

 

Pain With Eye Movement

 

  • Pain sensation worsening after movement of the eye ball is specific to typical ON. At the site of the apex, the optic nerve sheath is proximal to the superior and medial rectus. Consequently, when the patient moves the eye ball, contraction of the ocular muscles irritates the inflamed optic nerve sheath to cause the pain . It is less likely for patients with anterior ON to develop pain with eye movement, because the optic nerve sheath of the anterior nerve is not pulled by the ocular muscles.

 

Option C. Multiple myeloma is a common cause:

 

  • Isolated ON and MS-associated ON (MS-ON) are usually grouped together as typical ON, since they share concurrent characteristics, including age ranging from 18 to 50, unilaterality, pain with eye movement, rapid vision loss, and the tendency to reach the lowest level of visual acuity within two weeks of onset.

 

(Yang X, Li X, Lai M, Wang J, Tan S, Chan HH. Pain Symptoms in Optic Neuritis. Front Pain Res (Lausanne). 2022 Apr 14;3:865032. doi: 10.3389/fpain.2022.865032. PMID: 35498555; PMCID: PMC9046587)

 

  • Atypical ON, especially the neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder (NMOSD) associated ON (NMOSD-ON), is more commonly bilateral (around 20%) than MS-ON
  • For differentiated diagnosis, an oligoclonal band (OCB) is more frequently discovered in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) of MS patients (85%) than NMOSD patients (15-30%) . The presence of aquaporin protein 4 antibodies (AQP4-IgG), which are found in more than 90% of NMOSD-ON patients in conjunction with the clinical features, helps to diagnose NMOSD with high sensitivity (99%) and specificity (90%).
  • Due to its unique clinical characteristics, including dominance of male gender, a single attack, better recovery of visual acuity, presentation as ON at onset is usually in adults, but presentation as acute demyelinating encephalomyelitis (ADEM) at onset is mostly in children. MOG associated disorder (MOGAD) is increasingly considered as a disease entity distinct from NMOSD.
  • Clinically isolated syndrome (CIS) refers to that the patient underwent a single or multiple phases of neurologic symptoms that might progressed to MS but at that moment these symptoms cannot fulfill the diagnostic criteria of MS (Karussis, 2014).
  • Multiple myeloma is not a known cause of optic neuritis.

 

Option D. Oral corticosteroids are the mainstay of treatment:

 

  • Oral corticosteroid therapy alone is not recommended for optic neuritis.
  • Intravenous methylprednisolone may be used if radiological evidence of multiple sclerosis is present.
  • Oral corticosteroid therapy alone is associated with an increased risk of new attacks of optic neuritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A relative afferent pupillary defect is a critical clinical sign in diagnosing optic neuritis, highlighting the asymmetric impact on optic nerve function. Understanding and correctly identifying this sign is vital for early and accurate diagnosis and management of optic neuritis.

questions.text: A patient presents with difficulty in left gaze; right gaze is normal, but on attempting left gaze, the right eye shows limited movement while the left eye exhibits nystagmus. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Right Internuclear Ophthalmoplegia

 

  • The clinical presentation of normal right gaze but impaired left gaze with failure of right eye adduction and nystagmus of the abducting left eye is pathognomonic for right internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO). INO results from a lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), which disrupts the connection between the sixth nerve nucleus and the contralateral third nerve nucleus. 
  • In right INO, the lesion is in the right MLF, preventing signals from the left sixth nerve nucleus from reaching the right third nerve nucleus and subsequently the right medial rectus muscle. This results in failure of adduction of the right eye during attempted left gaze. The abducting eye (left eye in this case) shows characteristic end-gaze nystagmus. The lesion is always on the same side as the eye that fails to adduct. INO is commonly associated with multiple sclerosis in younger patients and brainstem strokes in older patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thyroid eye disease: While thyroid eye disease can cause restrictive myopathy and limited eye movements, it typically presents with bilateral involvement and follows a specific pattern where inferior rectus is most commonly affected (causing restriction of upgaze), followed by medial rectus, superior rectus, and lateral rectus (mnemonic: "IM SLow"). It does not cause the specific pattern of ipsilateral adduction failure with contralateral abducting nystagmus seen in INO.

 

Option B. Right 3rd nerve palsy: Third nerve palsy would present with a "down and out" position of the affected eye due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles. The patient would have ptosis, mydriasis (if pupil is involved), and inability to adduct, elevate, or depress the eye. However, there would be no nystagmus of the contralateral eye, which is a key feature distinguishing INO from third nerve palsy.

 

Option C. Esotropia: Esotropia is a manifest inward deviation (convergent squint) where one or both eyes turn inward. The problem is specifically with adduction during conjugate left gaze, not a constant misalignment. Esotropia would show eyes turned inward even at rest, which is not seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Internuclear ophthalmoplegia is characterized by impaired adduction of the ipsilateral eye and nystagmus of the contralateral abducting eye, with the lesion located in the MLF on the same side as the eye that fails to adduct.

questions.text: Which of the following is typically seen in diabetic retinopathy? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tractional retinal detachment

 

Explanation:


Tractional retinal detachment (TRD) is a characteristic complication of proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR). In PDR, new vessels proliferate and are accompanied by fibrous tissue formation. When this fibrous tissue contracts, it pulls on the retina, leading to tractional retinal detachment. This typically occurs as a late complication of PDR, following vitreous hemorrhage and fibrovascular proliferation.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Myopic refractive error: This is incorrect. Myopic refractive error is not associated with diabetic retinopathy. It is a refractive condition where light focuses in front of the retina rather than on it.

 

Option C. Posterior staphyloma: This is incorrect. Posterior staphyloma is typically associated with high myopia, not diabetic retinopathy. It represents an outward bulging of the posterior pole of the eye.

 

Option D. Retinoschisis: This is incorrect. Retinoschisis, which is a splitting of the retinal layers, is not a characteristic feature of diabetic retinopathy. It is commonly seen in degenerative conditions and as a congenital condition.

 

Educational Objective: 


Tractional retinal detachment is a characteristic complication of proliferative diabetic retinopathy, caused by the contraction of fibrovascular tissue that develops with neovascularization.

choices.text: It can be left in the eye at the end of surgery.
It damages the corneal epithelium or the endothelium.
SF6 and perfluorocarbon are commonly used viscoelastics.
It is used to maintain the anterior chamber during capsulorhexis and IOL insertion.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding viscoelastic substances used in cataract surgery? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is used to maintain the anterior chamber during capsulorhexis and IOL insertion

 

Explanation: 


Viscoelastic substances, also called ophthalmic visco-surgical devices (OVDs), are used to maintain the anterior chamber shape and volume during cataract surgery, particularly during capsulorhexis and IOL insertion. These gel-like materials protect intraocular tissues during surgical procedures and help maintain space in the anterior chamber, making surgical maneuvers safer and easier.

 

Other Options: 


Option A. It can be left in the eye at the end of surgery: This is incorrect. Viscoelastic must be thoroughly removed at the end of surgery as retained viscoelastic can cause post-operative rise in intraocular pressure.

 

Option B. It damages the corneal epithelium or the endothelium: This is incorrect. Rather than causing damage, viscoelastic substances protect the corneal endothelium from surgical trauma and phacoemulsification energy.

 

Option C. SF6 and perfluorocarbon are commonly used viscoelastics: This is incorrect. These are vitreous substitutes used in vitreoretinal surgery, not viscoelastic substances used in cataract surgery.

 

Educational Objective: 


Viscoelastic substances are essential in cataract surgery for maintaining anterior chamber form and protecting intraocular structures, particularly during capsulorhexis and IOL insertion, and must be removed at the end of surgery.

questions.text:
Oculocephalic reflex assesses the integrity of which of the following cranial nerves? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

1. III

2. IV

3. VI

4. VIII

5. VII
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3 and 4

 

The oculocephalic reflex, also known as the doll's eye reflex, is a brainstem reflex useful test for evaluating the function of cranial nerves III, VI, and VIII to determine brainstem function and assess brain death.

 

  • It is elicited by the examiner rapidly rotating the patient's head and observing the resulting eye movements. The test is performed in both lateral directions, as well as during flexion and extension of the neck. 
  • The oculomotor (III) nerve receives input from the vestibular (VIII) and abducens (VI) nerves, which relay signals to the brainstem nuclei responsible for generating conjugate eye movements. 
  • In a normal reflex, the eyes move in the opposite direction of head movement to maintain their orientation in space.

 

A negative reflex can indicate cranial nerve palsies or brainstem damage if the eyes do not move or move in the same direction as head movement. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The oculocephalic reflex assesses the integrity of cranial nerves III (oculomotor), VI (abducens), and VIII (vestibulocochlear), which are crucial for coordinated eye movements in response to head motion.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old female patient presents with complaint of sudden diminishing vision. On examination, relative afferent pupillary defect is noted in the right eye and the left eye is normal. Which of the following investigations would you do next? (INICET May 2022)

 

  1. MRI brain and orbit
  2. Myelin oligodendrocyte oligoprotein (MOG) and neuromyelitis optica (NMO) antibodies
  3. Blood sugar
  4. Thyroid profile
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 3

 

  • The presented clinical features suggest optic neuritis, which is characterized by sudden, progressive, and profound visual loss along with relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD).
  • The recommended investigations for optic neuritis include MRI brain and orbit, screening for circulating MOG and NMO antibodies, and checking blood sugar levels.
  • Brain MRI is suggested in every patient after the first attack of optic neuritis, as there is a high probability of developing multiple sclerosis.
  • Neuromyelitis optica (NMO) is a severe type of optic neuritis that can occur bilaterally and is associated with myelitis. The presence of MOG and MO antibodies can diagnose the condition.
  • Reason for checking blood glucose level-
    • If it turns out to be optic neuritis, blood glucose levels should be measured as steroids are mainstay treatment modality
  • Marcus Gunn pupil, which indicates RAPD, is a characteristic sign of optic neuritis. It is elicited by the swinging flashlight test, where the eyes' response to light is observed by swinging the flashlight multiple times.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Thyroid profile: This is generally not directly relevant to acute visual changes associated with optic neuritis unless there is a suspicion of thyroid eye disease, which typically presents with other distinctive signs such as exophthalmos, eyelid retraction, and ophthalmoplegia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of sudden visual loss with RAPD, it is crucial to perform a thorough diagnostic evaluation to determine the underlying cause. MRI of the brain and orbits, along with specific antibody tests for MOG and NMO, provide critical information for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management of optic neuritis and related conditions. Monitoring blood sugar levels is also essential, especially in the context of potential steroid therapy.

questions.text: What event takes place when the retina is exposed to light? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperpolarization, decrease in neurotransmitter release

 

The retina responds to light by initiating a process called phototransduction, which converts light energy into an electrical signal. This process involves the activation of rods and cones, which are the photoreceptor cells in the retina.

 

In the dark, the cGMP gated channels in the photoreceptor cells are open, allowing a steady release of neurotransmitters such as glutamate. However, when light falls on the retina, a series of biochemical reactions occur, leading to the conversion of 11-cis-retinal to all-trans-retinal. This process activates transducin, which is a G protein-coupled receptor with phosphodiesterase activity, resulting in the breakdown of cGMP. As a result of the decrease in cGMP levels, sodium channels close, causing hyperpolarization of the photoreceptor cell.

 

The hyperpolarization leads to a decrease in glutamate release, which ultimately triggers the formation of an action potential. This process enables the transmission of visual information from the photoreceptor cells to the brain, allowing us to perceive and interpret visual images.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperpolarization, increase in neurotransmitter release: This is incorrect because hyperpolarization of photoreceptor cells leads to a decrease, not an increase, in neurotransmitter release.

 

Option C. Depolarization, decrease in neurotransmitter release: This is incorrect because light exposure causes hyperpolarization, not depolarization, of photoreceptor cells.

 

Option D. Depolarization, increase in neurotransmitter release: This is also incorrect as it suggests the opposite response of photoreceptors to light. Depolarization and increased neurotransmitter release occur in the absence of light (i.e., in the dark).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Light exposure results in the hyperpolarization of photoreceptor cells in the retina, leading to a decrease in the release of the neurotransmitter glutamate. This process is crucial for converting light signals into electrical signals that can be processed by the brain to form visual images.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of complicated cataracts? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Krukenberg spindle

 

Krukenberg spindle is not a feature of complicated cataracts. The slit lamp examination in pigmentary glaucoma shows a pattern of pigment deposition on the back of the cornea-endothelium called Krukenberg spindles.

 

 

  • Complicated or secondary cataracts develop due to inflammatory or degenerative conditions of the lens or other parts of the eye.
  • Causes of these cataracts include iridocyclitis and ciliary body tumors which disturb the nutrition of the lens.
  • These cataracts present with a breadcrumb appearance and polychromatic luster.
  • Vision impairment occurs even in the early stages due to location of the cataract at the nodal point.
  • Inflammation of the posterior segment causes posterior subcapsular cataract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Polychromatic lustre: This is a feature seen in complicated cataracts where the lens exhibits a colorful sheen, often described as having a "christmas tree" or polychromatic appearance, particularly noticeable under slit-lamp examination.

 

Option C. Occurs after uveitis: Uveitis, an inflammatory disease affecting the uveal tract of the eye, can lead to the development of complicated cataracts. Chronic inflammation can disrupt the lens, leading to cataract formation.

 

Option D. Breadcrumb appearance: This refers to the appearance of small opacities within the lens, resembling breadcrumbs, commonly seen in complicated cataracts due to intraocular inflammation or other degenerative changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Krukenberg spindle is a vertical, spindle-shaped deposit of pigment on the posterior surface of the cornea, commonly seen in pigmentary glaucoma. It results from the dispersion of pigment granules from the iris that adhere to the corneal endothelium.

questions.text: What is the most common route of the spread of retinoblastoma? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Direct invasion

 

Direct invasion is the most common mode of spread of retinoblastoma.

Direct invasion included the optic nerve and the other parts in contact with the tumour mass. Thus, Direct invasion is a better choice. 

 

  • Retinoblastoma is a malignancy that arises from the neurosensory retina.
  • It is the most common primary intraocular cancer in children.
  • Tumours are composed of small basophilic cells (retinoblasts), with large hyperchromatic nuclei and scanty cytoplasm.

 

There are four types of retinoblastomas:

 

  1. Endophytic (into the vitreous) with seeding of tumor cells throughout the eye
  2. Exophytic (into the subretinal space) leading to retinal detachment
  3. Mixed type
  4. Retinocytoma: retina may be diffusely infiltrated.

 

The child is usually brought to the surgeon on account of a peculiar yellowish-white reflex from the pupil, sometimes called leukocoria or amaurotic cat's eye.

 

 

Other modes of presentation include a convergent or divergent squint, cataract, buphthalmos, hypopyon, or proptosis.

 

If left untreated, retinoblastoma runs through the following stages:

 

  • The quiescent stage: lasting from 6 months to a year.
  • The glaucomatous stage: results in enlargement of the globe, with apparent or real proptosis. Pain is severe during this stage but is relieved when the tumor bursts through the sclera.
  • The stage of extraocular extension
  • The stage of metastasis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Optic nerve invasion: While possible, it is not the most common initial route of spread but is critical once involved, as it facilitates spread to the brain.

 

Option B. Hematogenous: Represents the method for distant metastasis rather than initial local spread.

 

Option D. Lymphatic spread: Uncommon in retinoblastoma since the eye lacks significant lymphatic channels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Direct invasion is the primary method of spread for retinoblastoma is essential in recognizing how the tumor progresses and impacts surrounding ocular structures. This knowledge is crucial for effective screening, early diagnosis, and management to prevent advanced stages of disease and potential metastasis.

questions.text: A 3-month-old child presents with photophobia and watering. Which of the following cannot be the cause? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction

 

Photophobia and watering in a 3-month-old child can be caused by various conditions. Here’s a closer look at each condition:

 

  • Congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction: This condition typically presents with excessive tearing (lacrimation) due to blockage of the nasolacrimal duct. However, it does not cause photophobia. Photophobia indicates sensitivity to light, which is not a feature of nasolacrimal duct obstruction.
  • Congenital entropion: This condition involves the inward turning of the eyelid, causing the eyelashes to rub against the cornea. This can lead to corneal abrasions, resulting in both photophobia and watering.
  • Congenital glaucoma: This is characterized by increased intraocular pressure, which can lead to a triad of symptoms: photophobia, lacrimation, and blepharospasm (eyelid twitching). It is a serious condition that requires prompt medical attention.
  • Congenital distichiasis: This condition involves an extra row of eyelashes, which can irritate the cornea, leading to corneal abrasions. This irritation can cause both photophobia and lacrimation.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction: As explained, this condition causes lacrimation but not photophobia. This makes it the to the question of which condition cannot cause photophobia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction is associated with excessive tearing but does not cause photophobia. Other conditions like congenital entropion, congenital glaucoma, and congenital distichiasis can cause both photophobia and watering due to corneal involvement and irritation.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿ETDRS chart - Early treatment diabetic retinopathy study

questions.text: Identify the chart given in the picture below: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hess chart

 

  • Hess chart is a diagnostic tool used to assess the field of a binocular single vision.
  • It is used to diagnose and monitor patients with incomitant strabismus.
  • Incomitant strabismus is a type of squint that occurs due to the limitation of eye movement associated with paralytic or mechanical etiologies.
  • The chart consists of a smaller chart that indicates the eye with the paretic muscle and a larger chart that indicates the eye with an overacting muscle.
  • The field of binocular single vision is the area where bifoveal fusion of an object of interest occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: The Snellen chart is used to test visual acuity. Visual acuity is the eye's ability to discriminate between two points.

 

A picture of the Snellen chart is given below.

 

 

Option C: The Pelli-Robson contrast sensitivity letter chart consists of letters of constant size but decreasing contrast. It is viewed by the patient from a distance of 1 meter until the lowest resolvable group of three letters on the chart is reached. It is used to measure contrast sensitivity, a measure of the ability to distinguish an object against its background. An image of the Pelli-Robson chart used in the Middle East is given below.

 

 

Option D: The early treatment diabetic retinopathy study or ETDRS chart presents a series of 5 letters of equal difficulty on each row, with standardized spacing between letters and rows. It consists of a total of 14 lines having 70 letters. It is also used to test visual acuity. An image of the ETDRS chart is given below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Hess chart is specifically designed to assess binocular vision and ocular muscle function, especially useful in diagnosing and managing strabismus and similar conditions affecting eye alignment and movement.

choices.text: The parts of a pterygium are Body, head and cap

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of pterygium? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rate of recurrence is 95%

 

  • Pterygium is a triangular fibrovascular ingrowth of degenerative conjunctival tissue.
  • It is caused by prolonged exposure to UV rays, dry heat, etc.
  • It has three parts: head (apical part on the cornea, body (region between limbus and canthus), and cap (semilunar white infiltrate in front of the head).
  • Patients may experience itching and grittiness due to Dellen.
  • It can interfere with vision and induce astigmatism.
  • Stocker's line may be associated with pterygium, which is a linear deposition of iron seen in the corneal epithelium, anterior to the head of a pterygium.
  • The recurrence rate after simple surgical excision is around 80%.

 

 

  • Pterygium is of 2 types: 
    1. Progressive which is thick, fleshy, and vascular.
    2. Regressive which is thin, atrophic, and attenuated.
  • This condition can be treated symptomatically with tear substitutes for dry eye symptoms and patients are advised to avoid  exposure to sun.
  • Surgical excision with free conjunctival limbal autograft is the preferred treatment to avoid recurrence.
  • The recurrence rate of pterygium is around 80% after simple surgical excision. Excision together with adjunctive therapies such as mitomycin C or 5-fluorouracil can reduce the risk of recurrence to approximately 10%.
  • Reported Recurrence rate after P.E.R.F.E.C.T technique is 1.6% (Cornelius CR. Recurrence Rate and Complications of Pterygium Extended Removal Followed by Extended Conjunctival Transplant).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It is a fibrovascular growth: This is accurate. Pterygium consists of fibrovascular tissue that can progressively invade the cornea.

 

Option C. The parts of a pterygium are Body, head and cap: This is true. The pterygium is typically described as having three parts: the head (which is the part that extends onto the cornea), the body (the main bulk of the growth), and the cap or leading edge.

 

Option D. Has progressive and regressive types: This is also true. Pterygium can be classified into progressive, which is active, vascular, and may encroach further onto the cornea, and regressive, which is typically less vascular and more fibrotic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pterygium's recurrence after surgical removal depends greatly on the surgical technique and the use of adjuvant therapies, not inherently 95% as previously thought. Effective management includes surgical excision combined with conjunctival autografts and adjuvant therapy to reduce the risk of recurrence significantly.
