questions.text: The vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) functions to stabilize the image on the retina during head movement. What is the ratio of eye velocity to head velocity, known as the VOR gain?  (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1

 

The vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) gain is 1, indicating that the eyes move at a compensatory velocity equal to the velocity of the head, but in the opposite direction.

 

The vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) allows for eye movements in the opposite direction of head movement to maintain steady gaze and prevent retinal image slip. Nerves involved are 3, 6 & 8.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct VOR gain is crucial for visual stability. A gain of 1 allows for precise compensation for head movements, ensuring that the visual environment remains stable, which is vital for tasks that involve motion and require steady vision, such as reading while in a moving vehicle or playing sports.

questions.text: Two weeks after cataract surgery, a patient presents with pain, decreased vision, and redness in the eye. Examination reveals cells in the anterior chamber and vitreous haze. Identify the diagnosis and the associated microorganism: (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Endophthalmitis; Staph epidermidis

 

  • The clinical triad of pain, decreased vision, and redness occurring 2 weeks post-cataract surgery, along with anterior chamber cells and vitreous haze, are classic hallmarks of postoperative endophthalmitis. This is the most dangerous complication of modern cataract surgery, presenting typically 3-7 days after surgery as bacteria require time to colonize and multiply. 
  • The presence of vitreous involvement (vitreous haze) is a key diagnostic feature that distinguishes endophthalmitis from other post-operative complications. Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common causative organism, as it originates from the patient's own conjunctival flora and skin. 
  • The organism enters through the surgical incision and causes severe intraocular infection requiring urgent treatment with intravitreal antibiotics (vancomycin and ceftazidime) and possible vitrectomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PCO; Propionibacterium acne: Posterior Capsular Opacification (PCO) is not an infectious condition but rather a late complication where residual lens epithelial cells proliferate on the posterior capsule, causing gradual vision decrease months to years after surgery. It presents without pain, redness, or inflammatory signs. There is no associated microorganism as it's not an infection. Treatment is simple Nd:YAG laser capsulotomy. 

 

Option B. Toxic Anterior Segment Syndrome; E.coli: TASS is a sterile inflammatory reaction to toxic substances used during surgery (preservatives, endotoxins, or residues on instruments). It presents very early (12-48 hours post-surgery), not at 2 weeks. While it causes anterior chamber inflammation and corneal edema (limbus to limbus), there is no vitreous involvement - a crucial differentiating feature. Being non-infectious, no organism is involved, and it responds well to topical steroids. E. coli is not associated with TASS.

 

Option D. Sympathetic ophthalmia; Mucormycosis: Sympathetic ophthalmia is a bilateral granulomatous panuveitis that occurs after penetrating trauma, not typically after modern cataract surgery (it was reported with older ECCE/ICCE techniques). It requires a penetrating injury to one eye, leading to autoimmune inflammation in both eyes weeks to years later. Mucormycosis is a fungal infection seen in immunocompromised patients but is not associated with sympathetic ophthalmia, which is an autoimmune condition, not an infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endophthalmitis presenting 3-7 days post-cataract surgery with pain, decreased vision, redness, and vitreous involvement is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus epidermidis from conjunctival flora.

questions.text: All the following are functions of the superior oblique muscle except? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adduction

 

The superior oblique muscle is one of the extraocular muscles responsible for controlling eye movements. Its primary functions include:

 

  • Abduction: Moving the eyeball away from the midline of the body. The superior oblique helps in turning the eye outward.
  • Depression: Moving the eyeball downward. The superior oblique assists in looking down, especially when the eye is in an adducted position.
  • Intorsion: Rotating the top of the eye towards the nose. This is the action of rotating the eyeball towards the nose, which is an inward rotation.

 

These functions can be remembered using the mnemonic "SOLID," where:

 

  • Superior Oblique LID stands for Lateral (abduction), Intorsion, and Depression.

 

The superior oblique muscle does not perform adduction, which is moving the eyeball towards the midline of the body. This action is typically performed by the recti muscles, specifically the medial rectus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The superior oblique muscle is responsible for abduction, depression, and intorsion of the eye, but not adduction.

questions.text: In case of a chemical injury to the eye, what is the immediate first step in the management? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Copious irrigation with saline

 

Explanation: 


In chemical injury to the eye, copious irrigation with saline is the immediate first step in management. The primary goal is to remove the offending agent as quickly as possible to minimize tissue damage. Irrigation should be started immediately using whatever solution is available (saline, Ringer's lactate, balanced salt solution, or even plain water). It's crucial not to use neutralizing solutions (like acid for alkali or vice versa) as this can generate heat and cause additional damage.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Check visual acuity: This is incorrect as checking visual acuity would delay the urgent need to remove the causative chemical agent. Visual acuity can be checked after initial irrigation.

 

Option B. Take history: This is incorrect. While history is important, it should not delay immediate irrigation. Basic history (type of chemical) can be taken while performing irrigation.

 

Option C. Intraocular pressure measurement: This is incorrect. IOP measurement has no role in immediate management of chemical injury and could potentially cause more harm if done before thorough irrigation.

 

Educational Objective: 


Immediate copious irrigation with saline or any available appropriate solution is the first step in managing chemical injury to the eye, taking precedence over all other examinations or investigations.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of proptosis in a middle-aged person? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thyroid eye disease

 

Thyroid eye disease (TED), also known as Graves' orbitopathy, is the most common cause of proptosis in middle-aged individuals. TED is an autoimmune condition associated with thyroid dysfunction, typically hyperthyroidism. The disease leads to inflammation and swelling of the extraocular muscles and increased orbital fat, causing the eyes to bulge outward (proptosis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orbital varix: Orbital varices are venous malformations that can cause intermittent proptosis, but they are not the most common cause. They typically become symptomatic during activities that increase venous pressure, such as straining or bending over.

 

Option C. Retinoblastoma: Retinoblastoma is a malignant intraocular tumor that primarily affects children. It is not a common cause of proptosis in middle-aged adults.

 

Option D. Cavernous hemangioma: Cavernous hemangiomas are benign vascular tumors and the most common orbital tumor in adults, but they are not the most frequent cause of proptosis. These tumors tend to grow slowly and cause progressive proptosis.

 

Intraocular tumours

Most common in adults : Melanoma

Most common in children : Retinoblastoma

 

Intraorbital tumours

Most common in adults : Hemangioma

Most common in children : Rhabdomyosarcoma

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common cause of proptosis in middle-aged individuals is thyroid eye disease (TED), a condition related to thyroid dysfunction that leads to inflammation and swelling within the orbit.

questions.text: Identify the finding marked by the arrow in the below image: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vossius ring

 

  • The image shows a Vossius ring, which is a circular ring of faint or stippled opacity seen on the anterior surface of the lens.
  • It is caused by brown amorphous granules of pigment lying on the capsule of the lens and is usually seen after blunt trauma to the eye and orbit.
  • The force of the blow drives the cornea and iris backward, producing an impression of the iris on the lens.
  • The ring usually has about the same diameter as the contracted pupil.
  • The resorption of the pigment results in discrete subcapsular opacities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Weiss ring: Is a floater which may be seen by the patient as a circle or other large solitary lesion. It is the detached former attachment to the margin of the optic disc. It is seen in posterior vitreous detachment and is not confirmatory. It is seen in the image below.

 

 

Option C. A Fleischer's ring: Is usually observed in keratoconus, representing epithelial iron deposits. It is seen best with a cobalt blue filter.

 

 

Option D. Kayser-Fleischer ring: Is observed in Wilson's disease, due to intraocular deposition of copper. A brownish-yellow zone is seen in the peripheral Descemet membrane of the cornea. Anterior capsular cataract, also knowns as a sunflower cataract may be seen in some patients.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Vossius ring is an important clinical marker of previous blunt trauma to the eye, characterized by pigment imprint from the iris on the lens surface, mirroring the size of the contracted pupil at the time of impact.

questions.text: A patient of rheumatic heart disease who is noncompliant with treatment presents with complaints of superior field vision loss for the past 1 week. What is the probable cause of the given condition? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Branched retinal vein occlusion (BRVO)

 

A patient with rheumatic heart disease is at an increased risk of thromboembolic events, which can affect the retinal vessels. The key features presented are a history of superior field vision loss over the past week, which suggests a gradual onset typical of venous occlusion rather than arterial occlusion.

 

Key Features of BRVO:

 

  • Gradual onset: BRVO often presents with gradual vision changes, which is consistent with the patient's history of vision loss over one week.
  • Superior field vision loss: Indicates that the inferior retinal quadrant is affected, as retinal involvement typically causes a visual field defect in the opposite quadrant.
  • Associated with thromboembolic phenomena: Patients with rheumatic heart disease have a higher risk of thromboembolic events, leading to BRVO.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Branched retinal artery occlusion (BRAO): BRAO typically presents with a sudden onset of vision loss due to an acute blockage in the retinal artery. It is less common and would present immediately rather than over a week.

 

Option B. Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO): CRAO causes a sudden, painless, and profound loss of vision, not a gradual superior field vision loss.

 

Option D. Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO)

 

CRVO generally leads to a more severe, diffuse loss of vision, not limited to a specific field. It also typically presents with sudden vision loss rather than the gradual progression described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BRVO is the most probable cause of superior field vision loss in a patient with rheumatic heart disease due to its association with thromboembolic events and gradual onset of symptoms.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in the eye: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Canal of Petit

 

Canal of Petit, aka Spatia Zonularis / Zonular spaces, is a cleft or sacculated canal surrounding the lens between the posterior of the zonule of Zinn fibers and aqueous humor.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Egger's Line: This is a reference line used in gonioscopy to denote the anterior limit of the trabecular meshwork, not directly related to the lens or zonular apparatus.

 

Option B. Lens Capsule: This is the clear, membrane-like structure surrounding the lens itself, not the space around it.

 

Option C. Canal of Hannover: This is another anatomical feature in the eye associated with the zonular fibers but refers to a different part of the zonular apparatus than the Canal of Petit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Canal of Petit is an essential structure in the anatomy of the eye, playing a critical role in the stability and function of the lens. Its correct identification and understanding are pivotal in eye health management and surgical procedures involving the lens and surrounding structures.
